canonical_title: Is a 50-year mortgage really that much crazier than a 30-year one?

members.title: Is a 50-year mortgage really that much crazier than a 30-year one?
key_points: A 50-year mortgage is not as outlandish as it seems and may offer lower monthly payments, improving affordability for some homebuyers.
The U.S. mortgage system is unique due to widespread 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, largely enabled by government-backed entities like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
Long-term fixed-rate mortgages, whether 30 or 50 years, delay principal repayment and increase risk of going underwater during housing market downturns.

digest_abridged:
A 50-year mortgage offers lower monthly payments but increases risk during housing downturns, challenging the dominance of 30-year fixed-rate loans.

- New focus on long-term mortgage affordability and risk in downturns
- Introduction of 50-year mortgage as viable alternative to 30-year

key_points: The Trump administration’s 20-point ceasefire plan received strong support at the U.N. Security Council, with a 13-0 vote, marking a significant international endorsement of U.S. efforts to stabilize Gaza after two years of war.

The resolution authorizes an international stabilization force to provide security in Gaza, oversee borders, and demilitarize the territory, including the decommissioning of weapons from non-state armed groups like Hamas.
A transitional Board of Peace, to be led by President Donald Trump, is established to manage Gaza’s transition, with the mandate expiring in 2027.

members.title: Trump’s Plan for Gaza Endorsed by UN Security Council
key_points: The UN Security Council passed a U.S.-drafted resolution by 13–0 vote (with abstentions from Russia and China), endorsing key elements of Donald Trump’s 20-point Gaza plan, including the establishment of a 'Board of Peace' and a temporary International Stabilization Force (ISF).
The resolution grants international legitimacy to Trump’s plan and authorizes the disarmament of Hamas and other factions in Gaza, as well as the reconstruction of the enclave.

The Board of Peace will oversee demilitarization, secure Gaza streets, protect civilians, and escort humanitarian aid, with a unified command involving peacekeepers from Muslim-majority nations like Indonesia and Azerbaijan.

canonical_title: Rev. Jesse Jackson Remains Hospitalized After Receiving Care to Stabilize Blood Pressure
entities: US National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

members.title: Rev. Jesse Jackson Remains Hospitalized After Receiving Care to Stabilize Blood Pressure
key_points: Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader and protégé of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., remains hospitalized as of November 16, 2025, receiving treatment to stabilize his blood pressure.
Jackson has shown signs of improvement, including being able to maintain stable blood pressure without medication and brief moments of responsiveness, indicating a positive trend in his health.

His condition is linked to progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), a rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement, balance, and eye control, previously diagnosed as Parkinson’s disease and confirmed in April 2025.

entities: St Fagans National Museum of History

members.title: Royal Lodge to keep Queen’s playhouse Y Bwthyn Bach after Andrew eviction?
key_points: Y Bwthyn Bach was gifted to Princess Elizabeth in 1932 by the people of Wales and has been a longstanding symbol of Welsh loyalty to the Royal Family.

The cottage, designed by architect Edmund Willmott and built from leftover hospital materials, was a functional miniature house with working appliances, reflecting early 1930s innovation and royal whimsy.
It has been maintained by members of the royal family, including Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, who lived in Royal Lodge since 2004 and reportedly paid for its upkeep.

key_points: The U.S. has linked a measles outbreak starting in Texas to outbreaks in Utah and Arizona for the first time, signaling a national transmission chain.
The measles strain 9171, first identified in Texas on Jan. 20, 2025, has spread across multiple states, including Oklahoma, New Mexico, Utah, Arizona, South Carolina, and New York.

canonical_title: Scientists watch flare with 10 trillion suns’ light from massive black hole

members.title: Scientists watch flare with 10 trillion suns’ light from massive black hole
key_points: Scientists observed the most energetic flare ever recorded from a supermassive black hole, which briefly emitted light equivalent to 10 trillion suns.

The flare was caused when a massive star (30–200 times the mass of the Sun) was torn apart by a supermassive black hole 300 million times the mass of the Sun, located in a galaxy 11 billion light years away.
The event occurred in the early universe, offering a rare glimpse into conditions during the formative era of the cosmos.

timeframes: Tuesday to Thursday..midday Eastern Time (17:00 GMT)

members.title: Solar storms to hit Earth, triggering northern lights: What we know
key_points: A G4 geomagnetic storm, the strongest level of storm activity, is expected due to three coronal mass ejections (CMEs) from the Sun, with the most energetic one hitting Earth on Wednesday.

The aurora borealis (northern lights) are visible across multiple U.S. states including Illinois, Colorado, Massachusetts, Washington, California, Oregon, Texas, Georgia, North Dakota, New York, Wyoming, and North Carolina, as well as in Canada and parts of Europe.
Solar flares and CMEs, caused by realignment of magnetic fields on the Sun, are the primary sources of these storms and are part of the sun’s 11-year solar cycle.

key_points: Art by women is systematically undervalued in the market, with prices often significantly lower than those of comparable works by men.
The gender gap in art valuation is not based on artistic merit but on societal perceptions influenced by misogyny, ageism, and bias in auction houses and museums.
A 2021 study by Renée B. Adams found that artworks attributed to male artists were rated higher than those attributed to female artists, even when the works were identical.

digest_abridged:
Art by women is systematically undervalued in global markets due to gender bias.

- institutional actors in bias: auction houses

Wildlife trafficking in Thailand, particularly along the border with Cambodia, is a persistent and organized issue, with trafficking networks targeting protected species.

canonical_title: Granddaughter of ‘Charlotte’s Web’ author criticizes use of book title in DHS immigration crackdown operation

members.title: Granddaughter of ‘Charlotte’s Web’ author criticizes use of book title in DHS immigration crackdown operation
key_points: The Department of Homeland Security named an immigration operation 'Operation Charlotte’s Web' in Charlotte, North Carolina, using the title of a beloved children’s book by E.B. White, drawing criticism from the author’s granddaughter.

Martha White, granddaughter of E.B. White, criticized the federal use of the book’s title, stating that her grandfather opposed fear, unmarked raids, and the violation of due process, emphasizing the contrast between the book’s message of compassion and the government’s actions.

The operation in Charlotte resulted in 81 arrests over a five-hour period, with many of the arrested individuals having criminal or immigration histories, and led to business closures, including a family bakery.

entities: US National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

members.title: Civil rights leader Jesse Jackson to be removed from the ICU but will remain hospitalized
key_points: Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader and protégé of Martin Luther King Jr., is recovering from a diagnosis of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), a rare neurological disorder affecting movement, balance, and eye movements.
Jackson remains in stable condition and is being monitored at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, with plans to be moved out of the ICU later that day.
PSP is a progressive neurological condition typically affecting individuals in their 60s, with symptoms similar to Parkinson’s disease and leading to severe disability within three to five years.

canonical_title: What’s behind a surge in bear attacks in Japan?

members.title: What’s behind a surge in bear attacks in Japan?
key_points: Bear attacks in Japan have surged since April 2025, with 13 deaths and over 100 injuries — the highest on record since 2006.
Both big brown bears (Hokkaido) and Asiatic black bears (mainland Japan) are involved, with black bears causing more frequent attacks but brown bears causing more severe injuries or fatalities.
A primary cause is food scarcity due to poor acorn and beech nut yields, possibly linked to climate change.

canonical_title: Philippine President Marcos rejects sister’s accusation of chronic drug use

members.title: Philippine President Marcos rejects sister’s accusation of chronic drug use
key_points: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has publicly rejected claims from his sister Senator Imee Marcos that he has been a long-term drug user, which she alleges began during their father's dictatorship and continues today.
The accusations are part of a broader political and public controversy involving allegations of corruption, particularly in flood-control projects that cost taxpayers billions of pesos.

The Philippine government is investigating ghost projects, with officials accused of receiving kickbacks and using substandard materials or non-existent defenses, resulting in estimated economic losses of up to $2 billion.

canonical_title: Costs more than double to rebuild vital Baltimore bridge destroyed by cargo ship

key_points: The cost to rebuild the Francis Scott Key Bridge has more than doubled, rising from $1.7–$1.9 billion to $4.3–$5.2 billion due to inflation, increased federal design standards, and lack of preliminary engineering studies.
The bridge was vital for transportation into the Port of Baltimore, handling up to 35,000 vehicles daily, making its collapse a major disruption to regional trade and logistics.
The cargo ship Dali experienced two critical electrical failures due to tripped circuit breakers, leading to loss of propulsion and steering, and the emergency generator was not configured to assist.

canonical_title: How 'defund Planned Parenthood' came to threaten primary care in rural Maine

members.title: How 'defund Planned Parenthood' came to threaten primary care in rural Maine
key_points: Maine Family Planning, a 50-year-old network of reproductive health clinics, faced severe financial strain due to a federal law that cuts Medicaid funding for services exceeding $800,000 annually.

Despite abortion being legal and widely supported in Maine (72% of Mainers believe abortion should be legal in all or most cases), federal defunding efforts have disrupted access to essential primary care services, particularly for low-income and rural patients.

The organization cut primary care services at three rural clinics (Houlton, Presque Isle, Ellsworth) in October 2025, affecting nearly 1,000 patients, including many on Medicaid, due to a 20% loss of funding.

entities: Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez

members.title: Indiana Homeowner Charged in Fatal Shooting of House Cleaner Who Showed Up at the Wrong Door
key_points: Curt Andersen, a 62-year-old Indiana homeowner, was charged with voluntary manslaughter after fatally shooting Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez, a house cleaner who mistakenly arrived at his home in Whitestown, an Indianapolis suburb.

Andersen shot Rios through the front door after hearing a commotion at the door, believing someone was unlawfully trying to enter his home, even though there is no evidence she entered or attempted forcible entry.

Rios, a Guatemalan immigrant and mother of four, was part of a cleaning crew that went to the wrong address; her husband stated they tried to open the door with keys for about 30 seconds to a minute before she was shot.

The protest highlighted that despite national climate plans, global warming is on track to exceed the 1.5°C threshold under the Paris Agreement, with the UN Environment Programme warning of a 2.3–2.5°C rise by 2100.

members.title: A new virus variant and lagging vaccinations may mean the US is in for a severe flu season
key_points: A new mutated flu variant, subclade K of the H3N2 strain, is emerging and is driving early flu surges in the UK, Canada, and Japan.

key_points: The UK government, led by Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood, is reforming its asylum policy with the most significant changes in decades, making refugee status temporary and extending the path to permanent settlement to 20 years.
The reforms include removing automatic pathways to settlement after five years, requiring a review every two-and-a-half years, and increasing the pathway for those who arrive legally to 10 years.
Support for asylum seekers who can support themselves but choose not to will be removed, and conditional support will be withdrawn if they break the law.

canonical_title: Cambridge Dictionary’s 2025 word of the year captures an ‘unhealthy’ modern phenomenon

members.title: Cambridge Dictionary’s 2025 word of the year captures an ‘unhealthy’ modern phenomenon
key_points: Cambridge Dictionary has named 'parasocial' as its Word of the Year for 2025, capturing a growing phenomenon where people form one-sided emotional connections with individuals they don’t know, including celebrities and AI chatbots.
The term 'parasocial' was originally coined in 1956 by sociologists Donald Horton and Richard Wohl to describe viewer relationships with TV personalities, and has now become mainstream.

Modern social media users form parasocial relationships with influencers, celebrities, and online personalities, such as Taylor Swift and Lily Allen, leading to emotional attachment despite no personal interaction.

entities: Longest government shutdown in U.S. history

members.title: America is grappling with an air traffic controller shortage. Can AI help?
key_points: The U.S. is facing a persistent shortage of air traffic controllers, exacerbated by retirements and workforce attrition, which has disrupted flight schedules and contributed to the longest government shutdown in history.

AI has potential to assist in air traffic control by analyzing weather patterns, predicting storm risks, and providing real-time trajectory conflict recommendations, but it cannot fully replace human controllers due to safety, emotional nuance, and vigilance concerns.
Human controllers are essential for detecting subtle emotional cues in pilots or fellow controllers, responding to emergencies, and maintaining situational awareness under pressure.

entities: Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez

members.title: Indiana fatal shooting renews questions about stand-your-ground laws and their limits
key_points: The fatal shooting of Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez in Indiana highlights the risks and ambiguities in interpreting stand-your-ground laws, especially when a homeowner fatally shoots someone who mistakenly enters the property.

Stand-your-ground laws allow individuals to use deadly force in self-defense without retreating, even if they are outside their home, provided they reasonably believe they are in danger of death or serious bodily injury.
Critics argue that such laws can encourage violence and lead to racial bias, while supporters claim they empower individuals to protect themselves.

canonical_title: Scientists uncover an ant assassination scheme that helps a parasitic queen rise to power

members.title: Scientists uncover an ant assassination scheme that helps a parasitic queen rise to power
key_points: Scientists have discovered that parasitic ant queens from species L. orientalis and L. umbratus infiltrate colonies of other ant species by mimicking their scent.
The queens use abdominal fluid containing formic acid to manipulate worker ants into attacking and killing the host queen, a behavior not previously documented in any animal species.
This chemical deception allows the invader queen to take over the colony and reproduce with the help of her daughters, ultimately replacing the original queen and eliminating the host species.

key_points: The UK is launching a £45 million AI-powered project to combat drug-resistant superbugs, involving collaboration between the Fleming Initiative and pharmaceutical company GSK.

The project focuses on developing new antibiotics to overcome the defenses of Gram-negative bacteria, such as E. coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae, which have evolved resistance mechanisms like blocking antibiotic entry and active efflux.
AI will be trained on experimental data from molecules with different chemical structures to learn how antibiotics can penetrate and persist inside Gram-negative bacteria.

key_points: Chile’s presidential race is heading to a tense runoff between Jeannette Jara (Communist Party, center-left) and José Antonio Kast (hard-right, anti-migrant, anti-abortion platform), reflecting deep polarization between left and right on economic and social issues.

Jara, a former labor minister, won 26.7% of the vote, falling short of the 50% threshold, while Kast captured 24.1%, also failing to win outright, but gaining a strong position due to support from right-wing challengers focused on immigration and crime.

Kast promotes aggressive border security measures, including building ditches and walls along the northern border with Bolivia, and pledges to deport tens of thousands of undocumented migrants, particularly from Venezuela.

canonical_title: Canada's parliament narrowly approves Prime Minister Carney's first federal budget

members.title: Canada's parliament narrowly approves Prime Minister Carney's first federal budget
key_points: Canada's parliament narrowly approved Prime Minister Mark Carney's first federal budget, preventing an early election.
The budget raises the national deficit to C$78bn, marking the second-largest in Canadian history.

The plan includes C$140bn in new spending over five years to boost productivity, competitiveness, and resilience, with investments in trade infrastructure and support for US-tariff-affected businesses.

canonical_title: Shelters plea for Gazans as winter rains raise fears of more disease and death

members.title: Shelters plea for Gazans as winter rains raise fears of more disease and death
key_points: Over 260,000 Palestinian families (1.5 million people) are in urgent need of emergency shelter due to ongoing war and winter rains.
More than 80% of buildings in Gaza have been destroyed, with 92% of buildings in Gaza City destroyed, leaving most Gazans living in makeshift tents.

Aid agencies, including the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), have reported only 19,000 tents delivered since the ceasefire, with 4,000 pallets of aid (including tents and bedding) blocked from entering.

entities: National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art
Smithsonian’s National Museum of Asian Art

members.title: South Korea’s latest soft-power export? Late Samsung billionaire Lee Kun-hee’s vast art collection
key_points: The Lee Kun-hee family, particularly through its founder Lee Byung-chul and chairman Lee Kun-hee, amassed one of Asia’s largest private art collections, spanning over 1,500 years of Korean history.
Over 200 of the 23,000 donated artworks were gifted in 2021 to South Korea as part of a settlement for an inheritance tax bill exceeding 12 trillion won ($8.2 billion).

The exhibition 'Korean Treasures: Collected, Cherished, Shared' at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Asian Art in Washington, DC is showcasing rare Buddhist sculptures, sacred texts, antique furniture, and paintings by modern artists such as Lee Ungno and Kim Whanki.

members.title: A Chinese firm bought an insurer for CIA agents - part of Beijing's trillion dollar spending spree
key_points: China has spent $2.1 trillion globally since 2000, with an equal split between developing and wealthy countries, indicating a deliberate and expansive strategy beyond traditional aid or development finance.

State-backed investments in wealthy nations like the U.S., UK, and Germany are linked to strategic goals such as securing technology and manufacturing capabilities for domestic use, particularly in semiconductors, AI, and robotics.
The purchase of Wright USA by Fosun Group in 2015, financed through four Chinese state banks via a Cayman Islands route, raised alarms about foreign access to intelligence-related data.

canonical_title: Roman Surovtsev: Father Facing Deportation to War-Torn Ukraine After 20-Year Legal Battle

members.title: Roman Surovtsev: Father Facing Deportation to War-Torn Ukraine After 20-Year Legal Battle
key_points: Roman Surovtsev, a former Soviet refugee, was detained by ICE in August 2025 during a routine check-in, despite having complied with all immigration supervision requirements for over a decade.

Surovtsev’s 2003 armed carjacking conviction led to his permanent resident status being revoked, although his attorneys successfully vacated that conviction and are seeking to restore his green card status.

He is scheduled to be deported to Ukraine on November 17, 2025, a country currently under active war and martial law, where he does not speak or understand the language, and where he has no citizenship.

canonical_title: How will ‘limited’ US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?

members.title: How will ‘limited’ US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?
key_points: The U.S. is planning noncritical, non-explosive nuclear component tests, not full nuclear detonations, to evaluate weapon performance and safety without violating the 1992 test moratorium.

President Donald Trump has publicly called for the restart of nuclear weapons testing, citing concerns over China's nuclear build-up, but this has been clarified by U.S. officials as limited to nonexplosive system and component testing.
Noncritical tests, including subcritical experiments and laboratory simulations, are scientifically valid and widely used by nuclear powers to maintain weapon reliability without detonation.

The U.S. plans non-explosive nuclear component tests to maintain weapon reliability without violating its 1992 test moratorium.

The deaths were caused by physical violence, medical neglect, or a combination of both, as documented by Physicians for Human Rights - Israel (PHRI).
46 Palestinians died in the custody of the Israel Prison Service (IPS), and 52 died in Israeli military custody — all from Gaza in the latter case.
